title: How to Use Roses

steps.headline: Add them to food.
steps.description: As long as they haven’t been sprayed with pesticides or other chemicals, rose petals are edible. Use them as a beautiful garnish. Sprinkle them on salads or ice cream to add a subtle floral flavor. EXPERT TIP																															Pilar Zuniga																Floral Designer & Owner, Gorgeous and Green								Pilar Zuniga is a Floral Designer and the Owner of Gorgeous and Green, a floral design studio and Certified Green Business based in Oakland, California. Pilar has over ten years of experience in floral design. With a focus on being earth-friendly and supporting local growers, Gorgeous and Green has been featured in Energy Upgrade California, Molly My, Apartment Therapy, 100 Layer Cake, Design Sponge, and Trendy Bride. Her studio provides floral arrangements and gift basket, event and wedding design, and she teaches workshops on flower design and sustainability in her industry. Pilar received a BA in Anthropology from the University of California, Berkeley in 2001. Pilar Zuniga			Floral Designer & Owner, Gorgeous and Green				Our Expert Agrees: As long as your roses are non-sprayed or organic, you can use them in your food. For instance, place them on a cheese board to add beautiful color or texture to your table.

steps.headline: Infuse sugar.
steps.description:
Mix rose petals into sugar. Over time, the essence of the petals will infuse the sugar. Use your scented sugar anywhere you want to add a touch of rosy sweetness. Follow these steps to make your own:
Sprinkle thin layers of sugar and rose petals in a jar with a tight fitting lid. Begin and end with a layer of sugar. Close the jar and keep in a cupboard or other cool, dark place. Leave for two weeks. Sift out the petals and sprinkle the fragrant sugar on top of baked goods, such as cookies and shortbread, or add to drinks.

steps.headline: Make rose perfume.
steps.description: Unlike other perfume recipes, this project doesn’t require heat, so you can do it with a child. All you need are two ingredients: rose petals and water. A mortar and pestle are helpful when mashing the petals, to extract as much of the color and scent as possible. Cover 30-35 rose petals with water. Strain out the petals, saving the water, and mash the petals to release their color and fragrance. Return the petals to the water. Repeat these steps until the water is brightly colored and scented.

steps.headline: Create frosted rose petals.
steps.description: Give rose petals a glittery coating of sugar. Start with clean, dry rose petals. Brush one side with beaten, pasteurized egg white, then sprinkle with fine sugar and let dry. Top cakes with these sparkling petals for an elegant look.

steps.headline: Cook with it.
steps.description: Rose water has a concentrated fragrance, so use just a little to add a subtle floral perfume to foods. You can purchase it or make your own. Turn a regular buttercream icing into rose icing by beating in ¼ to ½ teaspoons (1.25-2.5 ml) of rose water. Add touch of pink food coloring to make it even rosier. Substitute rose water for vanilla in your favorite baked goods, such as cakes or muffins. The fragrance is more subtle when it’s baked. For a change of pace, stir a teaspoon (5 ml) of rose water into lemonade. The floral scent works well with the bright lemon flavor. Serve over ice and float a few petals in each glass.

steps.headline: De-puff eyelids.
steps.description: Saturate two cotton balls with rose water that has been chilled. Hold them on your eyes for ten minutes. Pat your skin dry; no need to rinse. Rose water is considered anti-inflammatory and is often used by dermatologists to reduce redness in the skin. It is gentle enough for daily use and for sensitive skin, as long as you're not allergic to roses.

steps.headline: Use as a makeup setting spray.
steps.description: When you’re done applying makeup, spritz a little rosewater on your face. It will set your makeup to keep it from fading and leave your face moisturized. This gentle setting spray can be used daily and is especially beneficial for adding moisture during cold, dry weather.

steps.headline: Care for your skin with a rose water tonic.
steps.description: Combine a handful of ingredients to make a fresh smelling tonic. Make a mixture of rose water, rose essential oil, glycerin, and witch hazel and pour over dried roses. Rose water is clarifying and energizing, so as long as you aren't sensitive to any of the ingredients, use it daily to complete your cleansing routine. Don't forget to follow it up with some moisturizer! Pour ½ cup (120 ml) rose water, 3 drops rose essential oil,1 teaspoon (5 ml) glycerin, and 4 tablespoons (60 ml) witch hazel into a jar and shake well. Pour into a bottle containing a handful of dried rosebuds. Apply your rose water tonic with a cotton ball to soothe and tone skin.

steps.headline: Make soothing bath salts.
steps.description: Mix together Epsom salt and sea salt, then add dried rose petals and rose oil. Use these bath salts to turn a normal bath into a fragrant, skin softening experience. Stir together 1 cup (240 ml) Epsom salt and ¼ cup (60 ml) sea salt. Crush a handful of dried rose petals and mix into the salts. Stir in a few drops of rose oil. Scoop bath salts into a thin cotton bag and tie the top. Add the bag to your tub as it is filling with water.

steps.headline: Create a rose scented honey.
steps.description: Mix together honey and rose petals to make a scented sweetener for your tea or fruit salad. Use honey with a mild flavor so it doesn't compete with the rose. Stir together 1 cup (240 ml) of a light-flavored honey and 1-2 tablespoons (15-30 ml) of dried rose petals. Cover and let sit for five days or up to a week. The longer it sits, the stronger the flavor will be. Strain out the rose petals and use the honey as usual.

steps.headline: Make rose scented tea.
steps.description: Mix together seven ounces (200 grams) of dried rose petals and 1¼  pounds (570 grams) of tea. Use a good quality tea, such as oolong. Store in an airtight, opaque container, and prepare according to the instructions for the tea.
